Hermann Kellermann, Der Krieg der Geister (Dresden, 1915). DURING WORLD WAR I, and particularly in its opening phases, intellectuals be- longing to the belligerent nations applied their moral authority and international reputation to justify the politics of their respective countries. Usually they em- ployed proclamations within the framework of a coordinated self-mobilization. The title of a contemporary book that printed these texts introduced the phrase, “Krieg der Geister.” In this war, prominent representatives of culture and science became uncritical spokesmen of nationalistic propaganda to which their reputa- tions delivered a high degree of credibility. 1 In Germany, official information gave the public the impression that the coun- try had been forced into a war of survival by its many enemies. The resultant solidarity appeared to have no political or social boundaries. Within this so-called truce (“Burgfrieden”), parties did not exist, only “Germans.” Intellectuals who distinguished opinions and value judgments from demonstrable facts in their pro- fessional work participated in the national euphoria and entered into the “Krieg der Geister.” At first glance, it appears that physicists did not differ from other professional or social groups in their commitment to their country. However, there were special efforts of self-representation. The Physikalische Zeitschrift printed the names of colleaguesfighting at the front, and of those who had been decorated,wounded,or killed.
